text: As someone having this channel as my only entry point to the broad world of programming related blog posts, I'm always puzzled. I have no idea of their relevance or whether they have audience and not a single clue to how the people sharing them discovered them in the first place. Also I am amazed by how plentiful they are.

text: Well, in some sense the internet was started by programmers to share stuff about programming and hobbies.

text: the blogosphere never really deflated

elements.text: the blogosphere never really deflated

text:
I wish I had a better feed for quality programming content.

There’s so much bloat of low-effort and low-quality posts. I found out GSoC requires blog posts and that lots of students will choose to post their progress posts on, e.g., medium. Also lots of like “data science work camps” will tell people to make blog posts like “how to do linear least squares” as a resume builder.

The closest thing I’ve seen is <http://lobste.rs|lobste.rs> but it is very sparse. I check it every few weeks and only end up engaging with ~5 posts in any way.

There are certain professors/researchers who have nice personal blogs, and I suppose I could set up an RSS feed for those

text: I think there are many RSS reader options (my gut says a terminal feed is probably out there). I use Mac and iOS, and unfortunately my preferred reader is only available on those platforms. It’s called Reeder (one time cost of $4-5 I think). Reeder is just a good reading app, but I like that it syncs my subscription list across my devices without needing to sign up for another service. There are plenty of good free apps too, and many browsers or email clients had RSS built-in back in the day.

elements.text: I think there are many RSS reader options (my gut says a terminal feed is probably out there). I use Mac and iOS, and unfortunately my preferred reader is only available on those platforms. It’s called Reeder (one time cost of $4-5 I think). Reeder is just a good reading app, but I like that it syncs my subscription list across my devices without needing to sign up for another service. There are plenty of good free apps too, and many browsers or email clients had RSS built-in back in the day.

text: Basically any time I come across a blog post or article I like, I go to the main page of the website and see if the other content also looks interesting. If it is, then just add `/rss` or `/feed` to the end of the URL (might need to also add `.xml`), and that should direct you to the XML that is the RSS feed. For my app, the XML URL will directly open in the app and ask if I want to subscribe. For other apps, you can copy paste the URL to subscribe.

elements.text: Basically any time I come across a blog post or article I like, I go to the main page of the website and see if the other content also looks interesting. If it is, then just add
/rss
or
/feed
to the end of the URL (might need to also add
.xml

), and that should direct you to the XML that is the RSS feed. For my app, the XML URL will directly open in the app and ask if I want to subscribe. For other apps, you can copy paste the URL to subscribe.

text: Works on almost every website I go to (I think it’s failed maybe once). RSS is still supported, it’s just not prominently featured on a site like it used to be. Works for some news sites too. Though for some sites (especially news) the RSS post is just a short blurb with a forward link to the actual article. That’s why I like Reeder cause it has an “automatic reader view” setting I can set per subscription, so that it automatically follows the forward link and renders the webpage using the apps “reader view.”

text: If you use the Opera web browser, you can customize your news feed with any RSS. Nothing fancy though.
